awd_abstract_narration:
It is uniformly agreed that civics education is an important way to teach the responsibilities of citizenship.  However, little is known about how teachers navigate this subject in a time of changes in government.  History teachers and Government teachers are being taught how to teach their subjects during a period of governmental changes in Kenya, and this research will examine how these teachers then actually teach these subjects.

Civic education has been seen as a stalwart for democratic processes.  This research examines how civic education might be changed as a function of teacher experience.  It will examine how changes in government structure are communicated to teachers in charge of teaching civics, and how they in turn teach civics to their students.  The research contributes to citizenship-formation theories and democratization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The research employed qualitative methods to better understand how citizenship is built in times of political contestation and change, and in particular, how teachers play a pivotal role in shaping future citizens as so-called "middle actors" or street-level bureaucrats. This will provide insights into how communities and states respond to electoral crises but also how ordinary processes of citizen-formation are conducted outside election cycles and typical civic education periods such as during election voter education.

I accomplish this through a study of high school history and social studies teachers and the revised Constitution (post-2010) in Kenya, and particularly contentious issues after the 2017 electoral crisis, and the post-election violence (PEV) of 2007-2008. The study has policy implications for civic education and peace education in ethnically diverse and politically divided states and in places were research has tended to focus on election-related civic education, without attention to the everyday citizen-education in school settings. I employed interpretive and ethnographic methods to explore new constructions of Kenyan citizenship. I conducted a comparative study focused on the teaching of high school "History and Government" in multiple counties in Kenya. Archival and secondary research was conducted in order to contextualize how contemporary choices about content and teaching pedagogy have been made and how they have evolved. I trained multiple graduate and undergraduate students from Kenyatta University and Georgetown University in archival and qualitative methods to assist with collating and coding the qualitative data.

This research will influence how scholars and education policy-makers approach questions of citizenship and national-identity formation. Development interventions  tends to regard civic education generally in the context of elections, particularly in the so-called Global South/ Lower and Middle Income Countries (LMICs) and in parts of Africa. These interventions miss the important between-election work occurring in places like high schools and Universities and the critical activities of non-state and non-elected but “political” actors like teachers. In addition, this study supports findings elsewhere that demonstrates that subjects like History and Civics are generally under-funded and under-resourced both in staff development and training, yet are crucial in democratizing and developing countries like Kenya and across in Africa.
